utterance.speaker: Chorus
utterance.content: Joy to the world, the Lord is come. Let earth receive her king. Let every heart prepare him room. And heaven and nature sing, and heaven and nature sing, and heaven, heaven and nature sing.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: This sucks. This is why we need to make a statement. You know?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I don’t think that —

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: What? You afraid we’ll wind up in detention?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Well, yeah. That’s… that’s what teachers do.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: They’re not going to send all of us to detention.

utterance.speaker: Rachelle
utterance.content: Mr. Henderson is totally lame and this is our best chance to inform him of that fact. You don’t think he’s lame?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Well, yeah, but…

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Then what’s the problem?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Announcer
utterance.content: The Robin Kay Academy Vocal Jazz Ensemble.

utterance.speaker: Ensemble
utterance.content: Chestnuts roasting on an open fire, Jack Frost nipping at your nose. Yuletide carols being sung by a choir and folks dressed up like Eskimos. Everybody knows…

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Mr. Henderson’s a stupid… Why… why’d you do that? I don’t feel so… so good.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: 16-year-old female gets pranked and also gets visual hallucinations and vomiting. Turns out to be a failing liver.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why have Foreman’s breasts suddenly started to droop?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Large breasts are a classic symptom of you letting Foreman take vacation days so he can finish his FDA reports before the end of the year.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When are you taking vacation?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Hepatic and neurological involvement —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So I understand Foreman’s absence. Your presence, not so much.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m bringing in a case. You may have noticed me doing that before.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve noticed you a lot recently. It’s almost as if you have a sexual interest in someone here. Like, say… Taub.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, Taub might think that I like him if I stayed, which is why I’m gonna do this.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Somehow I don’t think that was really about me.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Uh… Wilson’s Disease.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Ceruloplasmin’s normal.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You got a Christmas present.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: “Greg, made me think of you.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s funny. Usually explodes after I do that.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Alcohol abuse?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: She’s 16. The kind of boozing that destroys your liver that early, parents or teachers would notice. Wow. Manual of the Operations of Surgery by Joseph Bell.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You throwing that away?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Twice. Someone’s screwing with me. Forget it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah. Gifting antique medical texts. Oldest gag in the book.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Handwriting’s kinda girly. You got an admirer, House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said, forget the book! Why’d they pick on her?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: She’s an overachiever. High grades. She volunteers. She’s a big target.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m assuming literally. Depending on where this school falls on the Healthers scale…

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Do you think the kids slipped her something? Their teachers grilled them.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: When do teachers never know how to motivate their students?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: What did you do to Natalie?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: It’s all my fault. I didn’t stop her from being a total pig.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Your friend’s liver is failing. We’re doing what we can but she still might need a transplant. She could die unless you tell us what you gave her.

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: Just tell him.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Shut up.

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: We gave her some shrooms.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: We took some ourselves. We just… wanted to make her loosen up a little.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: How thoughtful of you. You got any left?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: They’re in Simon’s locker.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: This was your idea?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: No way. I didn’t give her anything.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Right, you just knew about it and let them do it.

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Poisonous mushroom and hallucinogenic ones are different.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not if they don’t dry properly.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Get back to school. You better hope we got to her in time.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Am I going to get in trouble? Should we apologize or something?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yes. You should. Natalie’s on the third floor.

utterance.speaker: Sarah
utterance.content: Who’s down there?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mr. Raditz.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Where’s the woman I spoke to last week? The trial patient, um, with the advanced symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She dropped out.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Is she okay?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not health-related. She just wants to drop out.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She didn’t say. And I only break into the houses of very special patients to understand them better.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I do good today, boss?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No rigidity. No cog wheeling. So, absolutely, I’d call that good.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Great. Thanks.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Your clipboard.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Keep it.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: This place actually smells of evil.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Where do you work, again? Why would House throw out a book worth hundreds of dollars?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: To make you ask that question. Can you really put a price tag on screwing with people?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Can you get us into Natalie Soellner’s locker while we’re here? House always has an agenda. Just screwing with us isn’t —

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Yeah. He’d never do that. Oh, wait. He already did, last year. Remember the Secret Santa gift he got himself?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He was making us fight over who could get him the best present. This time he’s just making us wonder. No animosity. No ugly competition. I think it’s a real present.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: If it’s real then House really was freaked. If it affects him, eventually it will affect us…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh-oh. Maybe it wasn’t those kids who poisoned Natalie. Maybe it was Natalie herself.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I didn’t try to kill myself.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Then why’d you have all those painkillers?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: In case I got a headache.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, maybe you took a few too many.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Do you have any kids?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No. But high school wasn’t all that different when I was your age. Teenagers can be incredibly mean. I know what you’re going through.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I bet you were cool. You’re pretty.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re pretty too.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I’m fat. I’m a loser. They all hate me. You know what they did last year? They took these photos of me for the yearbook. But it wasn’t. It was for this website, making fun of me, calling me a pig.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Forget about them. Let’s just make you better.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: What’s the point?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Acetylcysteine could save her liver, but we have to act fast. If there’s any chance that she took all those pills —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If it ‘s a subpoena, he’s gotten that kind of present before.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It was a book.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That narrows it down. Just look for someone who knows how to read or has been to a bookstore.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Most bookstores don’t carry Joseph Bell “On Surgery.”

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did it have a note?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Greg, made me think of you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Green wrapping paper.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: How did you know that? What is it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s nothing.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yes, when something’s nothing, the natural response is to guess the color of the paper it’s wrapped in and then descend into stunned silence.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Irene Adler. Christmas 2001. Sarcoid symptoms but she didn’t respond to methotrexate. I’ve never seen him so obsessed. He saved her with a last-minute Wegener’s diagnosis, but the hours he put in… I thought it would kill him. And then… Well, he fell for her. But it was too soon after Stacy and… It sounds silly, but Irene was the one who got away.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, you idiots. House is just screwing with you. You think there’s some woman with a mysterious green wrapping paper trademark?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Then how did you guess…?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I could be wrong. It’s possible a secret admirer gave House the same book I gave him last Christmas. And the same paper I wrapped it in. And the note I wrote.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Heartbeat?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: 150. BP 180 over 110. Crackling three-quarters of the way up.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Guess this means she didn’t try to kill herself.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, scratch the hallucinations. That’s from the mushrooms. That leaves liver failure and now pulmonary edema.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And you, standing there, beseechingly.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yes. I was going to stalk you at home but it was a busy week and your office is closer.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Thirteen and Foreman were busy drug trialing and we needed an answer on the overdose so we called her in. She’s just updating us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Convenient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Update’s done.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This is a good experience for me, as my parents never got divorced.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Theories!

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Glue sniffing.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Effects on the lungs would have been immediate.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: House. We all know what’s going on here. Cuddy gave you that present.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Infections?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No fever. No polys in the sputum.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I think… I think she loves you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I told you to lay off the present. and the LSD. We got distracted by the painkillers. Toxins are still the most likely.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Just tell her how you feel. If you won’t, then I will. I’ll walk right down there. Damn it. Love like this needs to fly free.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You talked to Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He has very girly handwriting, by the way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I knew I should have just wrapped a new present. You said the patient volunteered. Where?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Uh, Pleasant Valley.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Soup kitchen in Trenton. Thirteen, Kutner — go search the home and the school. Taub, you take the anal swabbing of the fragrant and contagious homeless men.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why don’t you just hang out in the video store and tell everyone Kevin Spacey’s Keyser Soze? By the way, that ending really made no sense at all.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You had my present for a year and didn’t even open it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had no way of knowing there was an expensive book inside.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Completely meaningless prank, even for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stealing your ice cream is a completely meaningless, albeit delicious prank. Observing my team’s reactions to unexplained phenomena could’ve been pretty useful.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Of all the ways to mess with people, why give yourself an imaginary present?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have you checked the prices for firemen strippers recently?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes. The holidays. They’re hard for you. I get it. You see the people around you giving and receiving gifts, having sustained, meaningful relationships. And, since you can’t, something deep in your subconscious makes you create the appearance of a gift. It’s sad.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You really passed your psych rotation?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s too bad you can’t just be nice to people. You could get a real present that way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I wanted gifts, I would just look deep into my patient’s eyes and act like you. “Oh, I’m so sorry you’re dying, Mrs. Moron. Of course I’ll sleep with you. What I lack in skill, I can make up for in…”

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You just wind up insulting her. Perhaps calling her “Mrs. Moron.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right, because I’m physically incapable of being polite.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Being kind in a sustained, meaningful way? No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, I get it. You’re trying to get me to prove you wrong. Then I’m gonna be nice to all my patients all through the holiday season and then Mr. Potter won’t steal Tiny Tim’s porridge. I’m totally on it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. That actually is what I’m trying to do. And the pathetic part is, it’s not going to work.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re right. I gotta stop being such a jerk. Oops. Kinda undercut myself there.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Janice? I’m Remy. I’m —

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: Yeah! I remember you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I heard you left the trial.

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If there’s some way I could help…

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: Um. It… it was that doctor. He… The one that was running the test.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Dr. Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He’s a great neurologist. He’s… a great guy.

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: Huh. You like him.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Why don’t you?

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: I told him that those injections were making me sick in my stomach and he just gave me antacid.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We were warned that nausea’s a side effect and giving you antacids is all he really could do.

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: No! He told me… “Get over it.” With or without these drugs, I don’t have a long time. I’m not gonna spend it being his guinea pig.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: House. It’s tuberculosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You got that from an anal swab? Man, you’re good.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It was a more subtle clue. Homeless guy, uncontrollably hacking up blood. Cough’s lasted two months. He was cachectic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless you can tie him to the patient…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yes. Again, if only there was some subtle clue like the fact that he was standing next to her in the soup line for a week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I hate spunk.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: TB can cause lung failure, liver symptoms… Fits.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start her on the standard regimen.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh, you don’t have clinic duty today.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who says it’s a duty?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi. I’m Greg.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: Hi. I’m Whitney.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hi, Whitney. How can I help you?

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: I have a… a terrible headache.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, I’m sorry to hear that. I’ll get you fixed up. Is there anything else you need like a bottle of water? Coffee? Mint tea?

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: No, but that’s so nice. Usually the clinic doctors are kinda rushed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you can’t be nice, why be a doctor. So, where do you feel the pain?

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: In the back of my head here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh, huh. It’s Beccaria’s sign. That’ll be gone by your third trimester.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: Uh, I’m not in school.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Neither is your fetus.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: Oh, God.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You didn’t know that you were pregnant?

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: How do you… You know that just from the headache?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do I know? I missed my period. I got fat, threw up. Oh no, wait. That’s how you know.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know because of the tight shirt stretched over the swollen boobs, the salt craving you imported into the clinic, the motion sickness patch that doesn’t do anything for the kind of sickness that you feel in the morning.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: I’m a virgin. So’s my fiancé.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I believe him.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: Aren’t there other ways I could get pregnant like sitting on a toilet seat?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely. There would need to be a guy sitting between you and the toilet seat. But yes, absolutely. I was doing so well.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Natalie?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’s having a seizure. Put her on her side. Nurse!

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not with the supple neck. I don’t know what this is. Four milligrams lorazepam.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Liver, lungs and now, brain. Which has mysteriously reappeared. Speaking of mysteriously reappeared…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Her ALT’s twenty times normal. Transaminases and PTs way up. She’s gonna lose her liver. We gotta get her on a transplant list.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You keep showing up. You also keep leaving. It’s possible that you have the hots for me but really, really hate this kid. It’s also remotely possible that I have that reversed.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’s a nice kid. I wanna make sure she’s okay. Hepatic fibrosis?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Normal complement level. Normal sized liver.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Does she remind you of… you? No. You weren’t a loser in high school. You had every Tom, Dick and Herschel wet dreaming about you. But she could be making you think of another helpless, chubby little girl you recently met.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re not really making this about the baby I tried to adopt.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Been a few weeks. Just enough time to get over hurt feelings…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Natalie’s 16. I think you’re confusing being maternal with being human. If we hadn’t ruled out the mushrooms —

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Maybe we shouldn’t have. Forget toxic, think allergic. Severe mold allergy could cause liver failure, respiratory arrest and encephalopathy.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: She ate the shrooms days ago. There’s no way she’d still be sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless it also gave her a fungal infection. Give her a prick test and antifungals.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hey. Thank you for the gift. I really appreciate it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I spoke to Janice.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Is she okay?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Yeah. Her nausea… She said you told her, like, get over it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Nausea isn’t something you can overcome with sheer will power.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which is why I didn’t prescribe will power. I prescribed antacids. If she can’t handle that, she’d have to leave the trial anyway.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Just call her, say you’re sorry. She’ll come back.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: God, you’re acting like House now.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, I’m not acting like House, which is exactly why I don’t need to apologize. I’m not being cruel. I’m not being manipulative.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You said the same thing to me when I told you I was having a hard time.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And it worked.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: She’s a 40-year-old woman who’s falling apart, physically and emotionally. She’s dying.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Look. I know seeing the ghost of your Christmas future is tough, but the only way I can help her is by making sure she follows her regimen, not by becoming her life coach.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You’re not acting like House. You are like him.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: Dr. House? This is my fiancé, Geoff.

utterance.speaker: Geoff
utterance.content: She says you told her you can get pregnant from sitting on a toilet seat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I said those words but with a particular inflection.

utterance.speaker: Geoff
utterance.content: I knew it wasn’t true.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: Well, isn’t there any other way? Isn’t it possible?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There was a reported case of a Civil War soldier who was shot in the testicles and the… musket ball carried the… non-musket ball into the uterus of a woman working in a neighboring field. Nine months later, a miracle child was born. Also, maybe she cheated on you.

utterance.speaker: Geoff
utterance.content: You made a promise.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: We do… we do other stuff in bed. Couldn’t some of his sperm have made it up there somehow?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: More likely, it came from the guy whose penis made it up there somehow but sure, anything’s possible.

utterance.speaker: Geoff
utterance.content: I want a paternity test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell him that amnios are dangerous this early on in the pregnancy.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: Are they?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who cares? He doesn’t know.

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: No, we’ll… we’ll do the paternity test.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No reaction.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: That’s bad?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If you had a mold allergy, it would explain your symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We’ll find out what’s wrong. Don’t worry. And, uh, I know some things are hard to talk about with your parents around, but kids can be really mean. There are people you can talk to, programs…

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I… I’ll be okay.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You’re in good spirits. You feeling better?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: No. I was just doing my homework. I’m such a dork, I guess that cheers me up.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Your parents brought it?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: No, Simon did.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The jock-y kid in your class?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Yeah. He just left.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Security?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: I was just bringing her her homework.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You helped bully this little girl and completely refuse to accept responsibility. No way you came here out of compassion. That only leaves guilt. What did you do to her?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Nothing —

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Stop lying or I’ll take the drugs I found in your locker down to the cops, you slimy little jerk.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This kid didn’t do anything to you.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: This isn’t about me.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah. I get it. You were bullied yourself when you were in school. Take it easy.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I wasn’t bullied.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Right. The Indian foster kid whose parents were shot in front of him. You were clearly homecoming king.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Let’s try this again. Just tell me —

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Honestly, you don’t understand. We used to be friends. And I’d be friends with her now if, you know, people wouldn’t make fun of me.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: There’s nothing you could tell us that’ll help?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Did she mention she used to drink a lot?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No. How do you know that?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: Look, don’t tell anyone, all right? I had my brother’s ID and I kinda supplied people. I used to get her a few bottles of vodka each week!

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Why’d you stop?

utterance.speaker: Simon
utterance.content: She got her own ID. Said it was cheaper buying it herself.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You can go.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I think we got our diagnosis. Our little girl’s a drunk.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I don’t drink. I did it back then, but…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You could die. We can’t get you on the transplant list until we know why your liver is failing. Alcohol abuse would explain that. The seizures could be from withdrawal.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I haven’t drunk in six months. I didn’t even drink that much back then.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A couple of vodka bottles a week…

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I didn’t open half of them. I just bought them because… you know… ’cause Simon was selling them. We used to be friends and that’s like the only way I could get him to even talk to me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Then why did you stop buying from him? He said you got your own ID.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: See, that’s not a good answer. Remember when you asked me if I had any kids? I don’t. I don’t know, maybe it has nothing to do with it, but I was good at school, good at work, lousy at life. I screwed up every relationship I ever had. I thought ‘why would I want to bring a child into this?’ But then I got older and… how you feel now will pass. Don’t let it screw up your whole life.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: It’s already screwed up.

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: My asthma. They said they’d fix it but it didn’t make any difference at all.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, sometimes doctors make mistakes, Anna. We need to try twice as hard to fix them. You using your inhaler?

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: All the time. Go through one a week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sure you’re using it right?

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: Do I look like an idiot?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Why don’t you show me how your inhaler works?

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: Jerk.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Uh, what was that all about?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Jamaican chicken recipes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The parents said no to the benzos but I still think Natalie’s not being honest with me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So she’s willing to die to cover up some boozing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’s very depressed. She feels like she deserves what the other kids are dishing out on her. I think she either wants to die or she wants the attention that dying gives her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have no idea why you care so much. Tell Kutner to start her on benzos.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, the parents just —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh, uh, uh. Not the alcoholism. Seizures. Totally different. Don’t need their approval for that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sure you want to know? If it makes it any easier, I’m going to tell you anyway

utterance.speaker: Whitney
utterance.content: We want to know.

utterance.speaker: Geoff
utterance.content: What does it say?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t leave.

utterance.speaker: Schmidt
utterance.content: You go home last night?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I meant to. Started reading this file and just couldn’t put it down. Let me ask you… That patient who dropped out, the one I told you about?

utterance.speaker: Schmidt
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You think I should pursue it more?

utterance.speaker: Schmidt
utterance.content: No. Patients drop out. That’s why we start with hundreds.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Well, I just thought, if there’s an easy way to make the people who drop off come back, then why not?

utterance.speaker: Schmidt
utterance.content: They’re not people.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Really? I thought the zombie trials were all completed during phase two.

utterance.speaker: Schmidt
utterance.content: You can’t see the patients as people. You can’t even see them as patients. They’re numbers.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Look. A friend of mine has this disease.

utterance.speaker: Schmidt
utterance.content: I don’t wanna know. There’s a reason this is double blind. Any personal stake we have skews the studies. Science is not about human relationships. It’s about results. You know that. You work for House. Why do you think I brought you on as my partner?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Her heart’s slowing down.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I’m trying. Push one amp atropine.

utterance.speaker: Geoff
utterance.content: Been waiting here for six hours. Am I the father or not?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. But, she also didn’t cheat on you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gotta tell you about this clinic patient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Natalie’s liver’s continuing to fail and now bradycardia. Atropine isn’t keeping the heart rate up. We’re gonna have to put her on a pacemaker.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Alcohol withdrawal would cause her heart to race, not crawl.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: There’s nothing structurally wrong with her heart. EKG, echo, electrolyte panel — all normal.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Multiple endocrine syndrome?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Free T-4’s normal. Hypothalamic brain tumor?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Didn’t come up on the CT scan.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s hitting all her organs. Could be the blood. What’s her alk phos?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It can’t be leukemia.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: High alk phos could also be from liver failure. She’s a teenager. Means bone growth and destruction could throw it off.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Maybe, but it’s higher than you’d expect. Start her on chemo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And do a bone marrow to confirm.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why are you ordering tests instead of treatment? Her heart and liver are about to give up. Do whatever you need to.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you so attached to this girl? It’s your call.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He doesn’t want us to treat her.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If it’s leukemia, even if we kill every cancer cell, her heart and liver are too far gone.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: A double transplant —

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: With brain involvement? The committee won’t even open the file. There’s no reason to put a dying girl through a painful treatment if you can’t save her. He’s being kind.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’ll arrange a biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Mrs. Burke? We are conducting another trial in tandem with yours. Same drug, lower dose. The nausea will be less. I did some checking. I can switch you. Here's the forms if you want back in.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What if we're wrong? Maybe we shouldn't have overlooked autoimmunes. High sed rate —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We went over this. Normal complement level.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: So it isn't hepatic fibrosis. Could still be microangiopathic vasculitis. With high-dose steroids, we might be able to reverse the —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You run a hospital that treats thousands of patients every day. Some of them die. Every day. If you're gonna get this worked up over every one of them… Yes! BRB

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What is it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you from a patient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: For you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I saved her marriage by showing that her pregnancy was the result of parthenogenesis.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Human parthenogenesis? You proved —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yep. It's unbelievable. But I personally checked it five times.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: How did you check it five times? The cycler's broken. You would have had to send it out. It would have taken —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, yeah. That does sound impossible, now that I think of it. I guess the better explanation is that the paternity test showed she cheated so I faked the whole parthenogenesis thingy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What? Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I win.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You faked a scientific miracle just to win a bet with Wilson?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mmm, more an argument. I realize it would have been simpler to just fake the paternity test, but hey — Christmas spirit and all that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I think you're confusing nice and evil again. Letting a woman deceive her husband by inventing a virgin birth just so you can—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And it obviously would have been more fitting if the baby had been born on Christmas, not just invented then.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's not leukemia. Seizures, liver failure — It's eclampsia.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which means we don't have one dead patient. We have two.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Um, you have a disease called eclampsia. It causes liver failure, pulmonary edema, and seizures. It's also associated with cardiomyopathy.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Uh, you can get eclampsia up to a month after giving birth.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Loose clothes. She's heavy to begin with. It was probably premature. If it was three weeks ago, they could have missed it on a physical exam. The baby's why you quit drinking, isn't it? Why you asked me if I had kids. Why you feel guilty.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Simon. He wasn't bad. We were like boyfriend/girlfriend for a while, we just didn't tell anyone. He doesn't even know about…

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I was gonna give it away. If they found out at school… I was at the Soup Kitchen and she started coming. There was this empty house down the street, but then she wasn't breathing. I tried so hard, but I couldn't do anything. I'm... so sorry. If I had her in a hospital, maybe she'd be alive.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The damage to the heart and liver are permanent.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I'm gonna die?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I didn't even bury her. I just put my coat over her.

utterance.speaker: Michael
utterance.content: Get out of my house.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I'm a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Michael
utterance.content: I don't care who you are.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Did you, uh... find the body of a baby?

utterance.speaker: Michael
utterance.content: I said get out.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: Michael? Who are you?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That's not your baby. You're tiny. There's no way you gave birth three weeks ago.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: She's my sister's.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That baby is sick. She needs clean water. She needs real heat. She was probably born with a partially blocked airway and… might even have brain damage. You can't take care of here in a place like this.

utterance.speaker: Michael
utterance.content: Shut up.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: I took care of her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I know. You found her. You saved her life. Now you have to let her go.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Who is that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It's your daughter. She was alive. People found her and took care of her.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: She's beautiful.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Kutner. No transplant?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We appealed. Too sick.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: How much time does she have left?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: A couple of days at most.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What about the baby?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Seems healthy, but it's too early to tell. She's in the hospital for observation for a few days, but after that —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Best case, winds up with her teenage father who just got voted captain of the varsity bullying team.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He's just a kid.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You all right?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Jonathan.

utterance.speaker: Jonathan
utterance.content: Yeah?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It's, uh... it's Lawrence Kutner.

utterance.speaker: Jonathan
utterance.content: Wh — why are you here?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I wanted to apologize. For all of the horrible stuff I did to you in high school. I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What's gonna happen to her?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I spoke to both sets of grandparents. It's too painful. They're putting her up for adoption.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What are you gonna do?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I already spoke to a lawyer. I become a foster parent and then I adopt.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Merry Christmas, Cuddy.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Where is everybody?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Down at the party.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I heard Janice is back on the trial.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: My Christmas gift to you.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I was wrong. You're not House.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah, well, that's my Christmas gift to myself.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We should go to the party.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We should.
